perfect-world-70k.title: Perfect World: Living on Exactly 7% Returns
perfect-world-70k.description: The theoretical scenario your brother-in-law described: $1M earning 7%, spending exactly $70K/year. This works in a perfect world with no inflation, market volatility, or real-life complications.

realistic-90k-lifestyle.title: Reality Check: $90K Annual Lifestyle
realistic-90k-lifestyle.description: More realistic scenario: $1M portfolio, but needing $90K/year ($7,500/month) for comfortable retirement. Watch how the 'death spiral' begins immediately as you withdraw more than the returns generate.

the-4-percent-rule.title: The 4% Rule: Why It Exists
the-4-percent-rule.description: Financial planners recommend 4% withdrawal rate ($40K from $1M) because it historically survives market volatility and inflation. Notice how this preserves wealth much longer.

with-social-security-buffer.title: Adding Social Security: Game Changer
with-social-security-buffer.description: Same $90K lifestyle, but Social Security starts at 67 ($2,800/month). This reduces the portfolio withdrawal to $4,700/month and dramatically improves sustainability.

inflation-reality-check.title: Inflation Reality: 3% Annual Expense Growth
inflation-reality-check.description: Same $1M portfolio and $70K starting expenses, BUT expenses grow 3% annually due to inflation. Even living 'within your means' initially, inflation slowly destroys the math.

sequence-risk-simulation.title: Sequence of Returns Risk Demo
sequence-risk-simulation.description: Shows why early market crashes are devastating. Same $1M, $90K lifestyle, but imagine 2008-style crash in years 1-2. Even with recovery, early losses + withdrawals = disaster.

what-you-actually-need.title: What You Actually Need: $2.25M for $90K Lifestyle
what-you-actually-need.description: Following the 4% rule: $90K รท 4% = $2.25M needed. This scenario shows how $2.25M can sustainably provide $90K/year indefinitely with 7% returns.

middle-class-reality.title: Middle Class Reality: $500K + Social Security
middle-class-reality.description: More typical scenario: $500K in retirement savings, modest $60K/year needs, Social Security at 67. Shows why most people can't afford to retire early.
